passage_text: When eye safety is a concern, polycarbonate or Trivex lenses usually are the best choice for your eyeglasses, sunglasses and sports eyewear. Both polycarbonate and Trivex lenses are thinner and lighter than regular plastic lenses.

Customer Reviews. The amber color of these impact-resistant polycarbonate lenses block short-wavelength blue light and 100% of ultraviolet (UV) light, thus providing additional protection against cataract formation and the development of macular degeneration, while increasing contrast on both sunny and bright hazy days.

Like polycarbonate lenses, lenses made of Trivex are thin, lightweight and much more impact-resistant than regular plastic or glass lenses. Trivex lenses, however, are composed of a urethane-based monomer and are made from a cast molding process similar to how regular plastic lenses are made.

While copper lenses block blue light better than the other lenses mentioned, they may be too dark for many to wear inside. Yellow/amber, orange and brown/bronze lenses still block enough blue light without the dimming effect to still produce some of the same benefits mentioned above.

Do they block so called “computer blue light or should I invest in clip-on lenses that do block this portion of the light spectrum? Written answer: Although polycarbonate lenses will absorb almost all UV light without the addition of a coating, it will not absorb blue light, so you will need a tint or clip-on lens. The best colour for blue absorption is a yellow or amber tint but brown will also be nearly as effective. Book an appointment.
